image.altText: Anthony Albanese wearing hi-vis and a construction hat at a press conference with Northern Territory ministers

props.synopsis: The federal government is promising $842.6 million over six years for remote Aboriginal communities in the Northern Territory, including for essential services such as policing, women's safety and alcohol harm reduction.

title.children: 'Won't be left behind': PM announces $840m for NT remote communities

image.altText: Man in a school attendance officer uniform

props.synopsis: Truancy officers fan out through Alice Springs on the lookout for kids who should be in school, with recalcitrant parents facing fines of $370.

title.children: On patrol with the NT's school enforcers as parents face $370 fines

image.altText: A close up shot of a woman wearing a white blazer and black and white shirt.

props.synopsis: In an ongoing defamation battle, court documents show Jacinta Nampijinpa Price says there was substantial truth to a media release calling for the dismissal of an Aboriginal land council CEO.

title.children: Price defends calling for land council CEO's dismissal, court documents show

image.altText: NT Chief Minister Lia Finocchiaro sitting inside a room and looking serious.

props.synopsis: As Lia Finocchiaro heads into her first full year as the Northern Territory's chief minister, she's promised "the end of this year will look very different to now".

title.children: Crime and economy the centre of NT chief minister’s ‘year of action’

image.altText: The exterior of the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre, with barbed wire in the foreground.

props.synopsis: A series of secret recordings of a detainee at the Don Dale Youth Detention Centre were thrown out as evidence in a high-profile murder trial, after a judge found they constituted a "significant" breach of surveillance laws.

title.children: Confessions of teen in Don Dale secretly recorded by justice officer

image.altText: Close-up of a lizard sculpture.

props.synopsis: A sculpture years in the making to welcome people to the town is in doubt after a government department threatened to terminate its contract with artist Steve Langton.

title.children: Future of Tennant Creek's giant Nyinkka lizards sculpture unknown

image.altText: Side-by-side photos of Bianca Jones and Holly Bowles, two Melbourne teens who have been hospitalised in Thailand

props.synopsis: Education Minister Jason Clare says it's "disappointing" that Laos hasn't accepted the help of Australian investigators. Follow live.

title.children: 'Disappointing' Laos hasn't accepted AFP offer on methanol deaths, says Clare

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Clare calls for answers to prevent further methanol poisoning deaths
PM's tense exchange on ABC radio
When is the next federal election?

image.altText: The front of a vehicle parked in a bay with a prominent shiny T badge.

props.synopsis: Tesla sales have declined globally, including a 30 per cent drop in Australia this January. Experts say it's partly due to Elon Musk's political views and high-profile actions deterring buyers.

title.children: Tesla sales slump off the back of Elon Musk's alienating political views

image.altText: A map showing the location of Starlink satellites

props.synopsis: In regional and remote Australian communities, Starlink is becoming the internet provider of choice but with that comes fears of what happens when they are forced to rely on Elon Musk?

title.children: Nearly 200,000 Australians rely on Starlink for internet. It's causing concern for some

image.altText: Brown water with a boat going past what looks like the roof of a pagola.

props.synopsis: The Bureau of Meterology is expecting more severe weather in north Queensland this weekend, while emergency services are focusing on accessing isolated areas running short on supplies.

title.children: BOM issues severe weather warning for flood-stricken north Queensland

image.altText: Travis Head, Dinesh Chandimal and Mitchell Starc

props.synopsis: Travis Head proves he is the ultimate golden arm and Mitchell Starc works wonders with both the old and new ball as Sri Lanka's risky selection call pays off. Here are the quick hits from day one of the second Test in Galle.

title.children: Quick hits: Head's celebration, Starc's mastery and a Sri Lankan gamble

image.altText: A mid-shot of Ben Dawkins sitting in WA's Legislative Council looking up to his left.

props.synopsis: An analyst says Ben Dawkins's name change to Austin Trump is an "effective" publicity stunt and a potential vote winner.

title.children: Outcast WA politician changes name to 'Aussie' Trump ahead of state election

image.altText: A man with glasses and a lanyard stands in front of a whiteboard.

props.synopsis: One of the "pivotal contributors" to creating the Chinese artificial intelligence chatbot DeepSeek studied computer science in Australia for several years.

title.children: Before helping to create DeepSeek, this engineer was an Australian uni student

image.altText: Minister Rose Jackson, with a political poster of NSW Premier Chris Minns behind her.

props.synopsis: While Rose Jackson has conceded the birthday lunch that helped trigger Jo Haylen's resignation was a mistake, the NSW mental health minister still has enough on her plate to worry about: the mass exit of the state's psychiatrists.

title.children: Why Jackson’s ill-advised long lunch could be the least of her worries

image.altText: Close up of some long grass at sunset, silhouetted by rays of light.

props.synopsis: Temperatures have sat in the mid-to-high 40s for most of the week across the Pilbara and Gascoyne with little relief in sight.

title.children: Severe heatwave persists in WA as 50C an outside chance

image.altText: Albanese speaks, a low angle shot captures his face.

props.synopsis: The battle to contain antisemitism in Australia finds both sides of politics embracing measures they would otherwise abhor.

title.children: Both Dutton and Albanese flip-flop as hate laws and civil liberties clash

image.altText: Dominos Pizza store with delivery bicycle outside

props.synopsis: Pizza chain Domino's says it will shut more than 200 loss-making stores, mostly in Japan. The ASX is on track for a weekly loss. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Domino's Pizza shares surge 20pc on 200 store closures, ASX dips

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Billabong, Roxy, Quiksilver unaffected by US bankruptcy
Furniture store Nick Scali posts big profit decline
Inflation is already 'sustainably' within target, according to ex-RBA economists

image.altText: A calendar graphic showing a potential election date and key dates.

props.synopsis: Trying to guess the election date before the prime minister reveals his thinking is always a somewhat futile exercise, but that has never got in the way of feverish speculation throughout the press gallery and beyond.

title.children: It's a federal election year. So when will the election actually be held?

image.altText: A young woman is taking a selfie with her two young kids and her husband.

props.synopsis: Frankie Jane Green and her family have to "share an address" with friends to meet school enrolment requirements while they search for a permanent home.

title.children: Family living in caravan fakes home address to enrol child in school

image.altText: A bucket of black snakes.

props.synopsis: More than 100 venomous snakes have been captured in a backyard in Sydney's west in what snake catchers said was their biggest find ever.

title.children: Nest of 102 venomous snakes discovered in Sydney backyard

image.altText: Quarterback Patrick Mahomes speaking to an NFL referee during a match

props.synopsis: The Kansas City Chiefs are on the cusp of making history, but an online conspiracy about referees favouring them has cast a cloud over the Super Bowl and forced the NFL to defend its officials.

title.children: A conspiracy about ref favouritism is overshadowing the Super Bowl

image.altText: A drone view of a town in Santorini, Greece, with white buildings with blue roofs, overlooking the Aegean Sea.

props.synopsis: A 5.2 magnitude tremor has been detected between the Greek islands of Santorini and Amorgos — the most powerful recorded since activity started on on January 31.

title.children: Greek government declares state of emergency as earthquakes shake Santorini

image.altText: A man in a yellow AFL jersey running holding an AFL ball.

props.synopsis: Foxtel apologises after inadvertently telling subscribers their services will be cut, but others are not so lucky.

title.children: Dozens of postcodes across Australia soon won't have access to Kayo and Binge

image.altText: A sliced egg on a bed of stewed greens in a tiny bowl. The yolk looks not quite set but not too liquidy.

props.synopsis: The idea of a perfectly cooked egg is subjective, but Italian scientists think they have cracked a method for optimising flavour and texture in both yolk and whites.

title.children: The 'perfect' egg takes 32 minutes to cook, study suggests

image.altText: A Tasmanian devil shows it's teeth under a tree, has white and black coat.

props.synopsis: Wildlife researchers say they have never come across a male Tasmanian devil with such markings.

title.children: 'Incredibly unique' Tassie devil trapped by mistake released into the wild

image.altText: Vladimir Putin sitting at a desk talking into a microphone.

props.synopsis: The Kremlin has called on the United States to develop a policy on ending the ongoing conflict in Ukraine and to outline the role it will play in negotiations.

title.children: Russia demands US 'formulate policy' to end war in Ukraine

image.altText: Workers dressed in blue in a factory work on a car.

props.synopsis: When it comes to gauging what impact the US president's tariffs could have, experts warn the space is highly unpredictable.

title.children: 'Is it worth it?' How Trump's tariffs on China could shift global trade

image.altText: Chappell Roan performs during the 67th Annual Grammy Awards.

props.synopsis: Have you been paying attention to the news this week? Let's see what you've got.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: Chappell's award plea, one big bear, and how Putricia smells

image.altText: Rebecca Nickels and her sister Hannah looking at bills in their shared Maddington home.

props.synopsis: Ten people crammed into a four-bedroom house with bunk beds stacked like Tetris — Rebecca Nickels' living situation is the reality for too many West Australians grappling with the housing crisis. So what are the politicians doing about it?

title.children: Three parents, seven kids living under one roof as housing crisis bites

image.altText: On the left, an undamaged building; on the right, a building engulfed in flames.

props.synopsis: The blaze, fuelled by flammable cladding on the building's exterior, killed 72 people and was one of Britain's worst modern disasters.

title.children: UK government to demolish Grenfell Tower, eight years after disaster

image.altText: A man's arms reach for a dirty air-conditioning vent in a ceiling

props.synopsis: Keeping your ducted cooling or heating system clean and well-maintained will help ensure it runs efficiently, and doesn't cause you health issues.

title.children: The importance of cleaning ducted air-conditioning systems

image.altText: A humpback whlae breaching the surface of the water.

props.synopsis: Scientists have discovered that human language and whale songs have remarkable similarities in the way they are segmented and structured.

title.children: Whale songs follow 'a lot of the same rules' as human language, new study finds
